topic.title: Using Multiburn to Update Firmware

body.p: Multiburn is a Microsemi-developed firmware download utility that runs in the GreenHills MULTI environment. It provides the ability to load firmware via EJTAG and is the most effective way to load firmware on fresh boards or bricked boards which cannot be updated via other methods. The procedure to launch Multiburn and download any firmware image is described below.

li.p: Open the MULTI Debugger.
In the Connect dropdown drop down menu, click ‘Connect…'.
In the Connection Chooser window, select a probe connection, and select Connect. A debug window opens.

Note that one MULTI board script, or MBS files, is provided with the PSX SDK PFX PFX-L. MBS files can be specified in the MULTI Connection Editor. The provided MBS file can be found in the <work space>/PM74605_psx_xxxxxxxx/etc <work space>/PM74605_pfx_xxxxxxxx/etc directory. The switchtec_fvb_reva.mbs file should be used.
In the ‘Trg’ tab at the bottom left-side of the window, type ‘tr’ to reset the MIPS processors.
Once the reset has completed successfully, the list of three TCs TCs list is shown in the debug window. Double-click the TC ‘Id 0’. The debug window on TC0 displays as shown below.
In the debug window on TC0, Select the TC ‘Id 0, and then select File => Debug Program. Select the multiburn.elf image file located in the tools/directory.
Click on Debug. A CPU connection window is displayed. Select the first option ‘Id0’ and click OK.
The Debugger Window on TC0 appears (see Figure 5).
Click the green arrow button ► or hot key F5 to execute the Multiburn image.

fig.title: Execution in Debugger Window on TC0

li.p: Another "Prepare Target" window similar to the one below will be displayed for initial running with Multiburn. Select the radio button “Download to RAM” and click OK. Once it returns to the Debug Window on TC0, click the green arrow button ► or hot key F5 to execute the Multiburn image.
Click cancel in the Prepare Target window
In the Trg window, issue a 'tr' (test reset)
Re-run from step 8
Once the Multiburn program is running on the target, a series of messages displays in the Green Hills debugger windows below the main debugger window. Select the I/O tab as shown below.
Wait for the input file selection prompt.
Enter the absolute path, from the host’s perspective, to the file needed to burn to flash memory.

When the Multiburn tool prompts to enter the file name of the image, specify the full path: <work space>/-[[PM74605_01_psx_xxxx_xx]]-+[[PM74605_psx_xxxx_xx]]+/images/xxx.pmc <work space>/-[[PM74605_01_xxxx_xx]]-+[[PM74605_xxxx_xx]]+/images/xxx.pmc(where xxx.pmc is switchtec_partmap.pmc, +[[switchtec_partmap.pmc, ]]+switchtec_boot.pmc, switchtec_bl2.pmc, switchtec_psx.pmc switchtec_pfx.pmc, switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc or switchtec_cfg_seeprom.pmc).
Note that switchtec_partmap.pmc should be the first file downloaded to a blank board.
The Multiburn tool will examine and output the header information of the file.
If the information is correct, enter ‘1’, ‘2’ or ‘3’ to select the method of download and activation.

row.entry: Download to both active and inactive partitions

entry.p: If the image is for the configuration file or main application, e.g. , switchtec_psx.pmc, switchtec_pfx.pmc or switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc switchtec_partmap.pmc, Multiburn flashes the image to both the active and inactive partitions.
For other image types, i.e. switchtec_boot.pmc image, Multiburn just flashes the image to the proper partition.

If the image is for configuration file or main application, e.g. , switchtec_psx.pmc , switchtec_pfx.pmc or switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc, Multiburn flashes the image to the corresponding inactive partition, and then activates the new image by toggling the active image/data partition flag.
For other image types, i.e. switchtec_boot.pmc image, Multiburn just flashes the image to the proper partition.
PARTMAP switchtec_partmap.pmc image is a special partition, Multiburn will handle differently, when choose this option, it will refresh both PARTMAP partition.

If the image is for the configuration file or main application, e.g. , switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc or switchtec_psx.pmc switchtec_pfx.pmc, Multiburn flashes the image to the corresponding inactive partition.
For other image types, i.e. switchtec_boot.pmc image, Multiburn just flashes the image to the proper partition.
PARTMAP switchtec_partmap.pmc image, never choose this option.

row.entry: Download to both active and inactive partitions

entry.p: If the image type has redundant partitions, e.g. , switchtec_psx.pmc, switchtec_pfx.pmc or switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc,or switchtec_bl2.pmc, switchtec_partmap.pmc, Multiburn flashes the image to both the active and inactive partitions.
For other image types, i.e. switchtec_boot.pmc image, Multiburn just flashes the image to the proper partition.

If the image type has redundant partitions, e.g. , switchtec_psx.pmc , switchtec_pfx.pmc or switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc ,or switchtec_bl2_xxx.pmc, Multiburn flashes the image to the corresponding inactive partition, and then activates the new image by toggling the active image/data partition flag.
For other image types, i.e. switchtec_boot.pmc image, Multiburn just flashes the image to the proper partition.
PARTMAP switchtec_partmap.pmc image is a special partition, Multiburn will handle differently, when choose this option, it will refresh both PARTMAP partition.

If the image type has redundant partitions, e.g. , switchtec_psx.pmc , switchtec_pfx.pmc or switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc ,or switchtec_bl2_xxx.pmc, Multiburn flashes the image to the corresponding inactive partition.
For other image types, i.e. switchtec_boot.pmc image, Multiburn just flashes the image to the proper partition.
PARTMAP switchtec_partmap.pmc image, never choose this option.

li.p: Make sure downloading the switchtec_partmap.pmc is the first step in flashing images to a new target board. Multiburn needs to access the PARTMAP when flashing the configuration file or main application image, and accessing an uninitialized PARTMAP will cause ECC errors when ECC is enabled.
Microsemi recommends using method ‘1’ for flashing main firmware images and configuration file images to a new PSX PFX PFX-L board. Option '2' is recommended when the PARTMAP image is downloaded.

Before updating MAIN_FW or/and CFG_DATA flash partition in non-new board, users need to check the major number of XML version.Details see case a and b as below. If the major number of XML versions are different, option'1' of multiburn is a MUST.
Here, MAIN_FW binary is .switchtec_psx.pmc , switchtec_pfx.pmc; CFG_DATA binary is switchtec_cfg_xxx.pmc.

Case a. If updating CFG_DATA partition with a new CFG_DATA binary, please check the major number of the new CFG_DATA binary and the major number of active MAIN_FW partition in flash. The active MAIN_FW partition is the one already in Switchtec flash.

Case b. If updating MAIN_FW partition with a new MAIN_FW binary, please check the major number of the new MAIN_FW binary and the major number of active CFG_DATA partition in flash. The active CFG_DATA partition is the one already in Switchtec flash.

The XML version of switchtec_xxx.pmc file is located in the file header(i.e. meta-data), and the XML version of a flash partition is located at the last 256bytes of each flash partitions(i.e. meta-data). Meta-data structure is referred to <Partition Meta-data> in SPI Flash Partition Layout
Users can use the commands to check XML version of flash partitions on a running switchtec board:
CLI command : fw_part -p <flash partition id>

p.i: <flash partition id> is referred to System Information Region

li.p: MRPC command : Get Partition Info command, refer to Get Partition Info Command
